articles.headline: Leno Blesses ‘Tonight Show’ Succession Plan
articles.snippet: NBC confirmed that Jimmy Fallon would take over from Jay Leno as host of “The Tonight Show” after the conclusion of the Winter Olympics in February 2014.
articles.abstract: NBC confirmed that Jimmy Fallon would take over from Jay Leno as host of “The Tonight Show” after the conclusion of the Winter Olympics in February 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steve Burke had seen enough. For months, the NBC chief executive had been involved in efforts to create a smooth transition at the “Tonight” show. Yet for most of March, after Jay Leno had been taken to task by a network executive over jokes about NBC’s poor ratings, the news media were full of reports that the network once again was mishandling its most storied late-night franchise.

articles.headline: Breaking Free of the Cellphone Carrier Conspiracy
articles.snippet: T-Mobile, the smallest of the Big Four cellphone carriers, steps away from the two-year, unbreakable contract that Sprint, Verizon and AT&T live by.
articles.abstract: T-Mobile, the smallest of the Big Four cellphone carriers, steps away from the two-year, unbreakable contract that Sprint, Verizon and AT&T live by.
articles.lead_paragraph: Where, exactly, is your threshold for outrage?

articles.headline: Airports in China Hew to an Unswerving Flight Path
articles.snippet: Terminal 2 at Hongqiao International Airport demonstrates China’s ability to move huge projects forward efficiently.
articles.abstract: Terminal 2 at Hongqiao International Airport demonstrates China’s ability to move huge projects forward efficiently.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — For those frustrated with air travel in the United States, arriving at this city’s domestic airport can be a treat.

articles.headline: Power Struggle Is Gripping Iran Ahead of June Election
articles.snippet: With only months to go in his last presidential term, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has surprised many of his critics by challenging a coalition of traditionalists.
articles.abstract: With only months to go in his last presidential term, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has surprised many of his critics by challenging a coalition of traditionalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — PresidentMahmoud Ahmadinejad is not going quietly.

articles.headline: Suit by Ex-Wife of SAC’s Cohen Revived on Appeal
articles.snippet: An appeals court has ordered the suit back to a lower court.
articles.abstract: An appeals court has ordered the suit back to a lower court.
articles.lead_paragraph: While the billionaire Steven A. Cohen has come under mounting scrutiny related to insider trading, he had reason to believe that a nasty court battle with his former wife was behind him.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Carol Vogel

articles.headline: Facebook Is Expected to Introduce Its Phone
articles.snippet: Facebook is expected to introduce a Facebook-centric phone on Thursday that is intended to help increase its profit overseas.
articles.abstract: Facebook is expected to introduce a Facebook-centric phone on Thursday that is intended to help increase its profit overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook does not have to build a phone, as its chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has long maintained.

articles.headline: Blame Abounds Over a Flawed Foreclosure Review
articles.snippet: A report cites failures by federal regulators, and further government scrutiny of them and of the consulting firms they hired to conduct the review is certain.
articles.abstract: A report cites failures by federal regulators, and further government scrutiny of them and of the consulting firms they hired to conduct the review is certain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private consultants and federal regulators are facing a fresh round of scrutiny in Washington after botching a broad review of foreclosures and failing to thwart financial misdeeds.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Walmart Strains to Keep Aisles Stocked Fresh
articles.snippet: The retailer is grappling with low customer confidence after it cut so many workers that it cannot stock its shelves properly, according to some employees and industry analysts.
articles.abstract: The retailer is grappling with low customer confidence after it cut so many workers that it cannot stock its shelves properly, according to some employees and industry analysts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama visited a Walmart in February to extol the fresh, healthy food in the company’s grocery aisles. But Walmart, Ms. Obama’s corporate partner in a campaign to make food healthier and more affordable, has been running into problems with food that is not so fresh.

articles.headline: As Web Search Goes Mobile, Competitors Chip at Google’s Lead
articles.snippet: Though Google is the undisputed king of search, alternative services are chipping into its share of the market.
articles.abstract: Though Google is the undisputed king of search, alternative services are chipping into its share of the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Say you need a latté. You might pull out your phone, open the Yelp app and search for a nearby cafe. If instead you want to buy an espresso machine, you will most likely tap Amazon.com.

articles.headline: Upstart Group Pushes Harder Than the N.R.A.
articles.snippet: Although dwarfed by the National Rifle Association, Gun Owners of America has grown in influence since the debate over gun control has surged.
articles.abstract: Although dwarfed by the National Rifle Association, Gun Owners of America has grown in influence since the debate over gun control has surged.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Va. — When word surfaced in February that Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, was plotting with Democrats on a bill to expand background checks for gun buyers, Larry Pratt got really mad. Then, Mr. Pratt, the executive director of Gun Owners of America, got busy, mounting a lobbying blitz that helps explain why a bipartisan Senate deal on background checks remains elusive.

articles.headline: Japan Initiates Bold Bid to End Years of Tumbling Prices
articles.snippet: Japan’s central bank said that it would aggressively buy bonds, doubling the amount of money in circulation over two years.
articles.abstract: Japan’s central bank said that it would aggressively buy bonds, doubling the amount of money in circulation over two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Haruhiko Kuroda, the new governor of the Bank of Japan, delivered on his promise to drastically change Japan’s economic policy to end a long, debilitating era of deflation.
